title: How to Wash Silk Pillowcases by Hand

steps.headline: Press a wet cloth on your silk to see if any color runs out.
steps.description: It’s important to do a color test on your silk pillowcase before you wash it to see if any color is going to run. Get a washcloth slightly damp and press it on a corner of the pillowcase. If any color comes off onto the washcloth, it is best to get your silk professionally dry cleaned. The dye from silk can stain your clothes and skin if it runs off when wet. Most pillowcases are made to be cleaned regularly, so they probably won’t need to be dry cleaned. However, it never hurts to check.

steps.headline: Blot any stains with a silk stain remover.
steps.description: If your pillowcase is stained, spray some silk stain remover on each area. Make sure that you are only spraying the stained areas of the pillowcase and not the entire thing. You can purchase silk stain remover at most home goods stores or online.

steps.headline: Mix lukewarm warm water and ⁄2 US tbsp (7.4 mL) of gentle detergent in a bucket.
steps.description: Fill a 2 US gal (7.6 L) bucket about ½ way with water that is just above room temperature. Pour a gentle laundry detergent into the water and mix it slightly with your hands to disperse it.Warning: Do not use water warmer than 30 °C (86 °F), or it could damage your pillowcase. You can purchase a detergent that is specifically for silk or use a gentle one with no added colors or fragrances.

steps.headline: Soak the pillowcase in the detergent and water for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Place your pillowcase into the bucket and submerge it fully. Allow it to soak for no more than 5 minutes. You can gently swirl your pillowcase as it soaks, but never scrub or wring it out. If you soak your pillowcase for longer than 5 minutes, it could shrink.

steps.headline: Drain the bucket and fill it with cool water, vinegar, and fabric softener.
steps.description: Dump out the warm water and detergent and rinse your bucket. Fill the 2 US gal (7.6 L) bucket about ½ way with cool water, ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of white vinegar, and 2 to 3 drops of fabric softener. White vinegar will remove any soap residue left over as well as brighten your pillowcase and remove any residual odors. Fabric softener leaves your pillowcase feeling silky and soft.

steps.headline: Let the pillowcase soak for 1 minute.
steps.description: Submerge your pillowcase fully into your bucket. Swirl the pillowcase around gently and then set a timer for 1 minute. Remove the pillowcase immediately after the minute is up. Your water will not bubble or suds up since there is no soap in this mixture.

steps.headline: Rinse your pillowcase with cool water.
steps.description: Drain your bucket and rinse it out. Fill it up with room temperature water. Submerge your pillowcase in the water and swirl it around gently. Make sure there is no soap or vinegar residue left on it.Tip: If your mixture was super soapy, you may have to rinse your pillowcase twice.

steps.headline: Lay your pillowcase flat on a towel.
steps.description: Put a clean, dry towel down on a flat surface like a table or countertop. Lay your pillowcase out flat on the towel. Make sure none of the corners or edges are creased or folded. Laying the pillowcase flat now will prevent wrinkles as it dries.

steps.headline: Roll up the towel with the pillowcase inside of it.
steps.description: Start with one end of the towel and roll it inwards on top of itself to create a spiral shape. Gently squeeze the spiral to press out any excess water that is still in the pillowcase. Do not twist or wring the pillowcase inside of the towel. This could damage your pillowcase.

steps.headline: Spread the pillowcase out on a new towel and let it dry.
steps.description: Lay out a clean, dry towel on a flat surface. Unroll your pillowcase from the other towel and spread it out fully on the clean towel. Make sure it is not creased or folded anywhere. Wait up to 2 days for your pillowcase to fully dry.Warning: Never hang your silk pillowcase to dry. Hanging can damage the fibers in silk and weaken them over time. You should also never dry your pillowcase outside, since the sun can discolor silk.
